items.name: Int
items.docComment: An integer number
Add two ints
Substract two ints
Multiply two ints
Divide two ints

Exponentiation
 
 ```kestrel
 2 ^ 3 // => 8
 ```

Modulo operator
 
 ```kestrel
 10 % 2 // => 0
 11 % 2 // => 1
 ```

items.name: Float
items.docComment:
A floating point number.
 
 Infix operations that deal with `Float` follow the convention of having a trailing `.`
 This is necessary to distinguish them from `Int` operators
Add two floats
Substract two floats
Multiply two floats
Divide two floats

items.name: Bool
items.docComment:
A boolean value that can either be `True` or `False`.
 
 Note that this isn't a builtin type, but a regular union type

Logic `and` between booleans
 
 ```kestrel
 True && True // => True
 True && False // => False
 False && True // => False
 False && False // => False
 ```

Logic `or` between booleans
 
 ```kestrel
 True && True // => True
 True && False // => True
 False && True // => True
 False && False // => False
 ```

Logic `not`
 
 ```kestrel
 !True // => False
 !False // => True
 ```

items.signature: Fn(a, a) -> Bool where a: Eq
items.docComment:
Perform structural equality between values.
 
 Requires values to implement the `Eq` trait, therefore
 equality is only supported for values of type:
 * `Int`
 * `Float`
 * `Char`
 * Union types whose constructors arguments support equality
 
 This mean that equality is supported, for example, for values of type `List<(String, Char)>`
 
 Equality between all the other values (for example functions or internal opaque types)
 is forbidden by the type system

items.signature: Fn(a, a) -> Bool where a: Eq
items.docComment: Same as `==`, but with negation

items.signature: Fn(a, a) -> Bool where a: Ord
Fn(a, a) -> Bool where a: Ord
Fn(a, a) -> Bool where a: Ord
Fn(a, a) -> Bool where a: Ord

items.name: Char
items.docComment:
A single `unicode` character.
 
 You can write chars with the `'` syntax, e.g. `'a'`
 (note the single quote, unlike in javascript)

items.name: Unit
items.docComment:
`Unit` is a `Tuple` with zero values. It only has one value: `Unit`
 Can be used in a similar way to `undefined` in javascript, to represent values that do not
 actually bring any meaningful information
 
 For example:
 * You can use the type `Result<Unit, String>` to represent values that can either fail (with a `String` error message)
 or succeed, without yielding any particular value. This is more idiomatic that representing error as `Maybe<String>`
 * You can use the type `Task<Unit>` to represent a computation the doesn't yield any value. This is actually the type required by the `main` value
 
 **note** if you are trying to represent a value that can either be of the type `T` or undefined, `Maybe<T>` might be what you are looking for.

items.name: Tuple2
items.docComment: A tuple containing 2 values

items.name: Tuple3
items.docComment: A tuple containing 3 values

items.name: Tuple4
items.docComment: A tuple containing 4 values

Tuple.moduleDoc:
The `Tuple` module contains tuples utilities.
 A sintax sugar for writing tuples is available,
 e.g. `("a", "b")` will desugar to `Tuple.Tuple2("a", "b")` when used as a value, whereas
 `(Int, Float)` will desguar to `Tuple.Tuple2<Int, Float>` when used as a type.

items.name: Option
items.docComment: A type representing an value that might be either present (`Some`) or absent (`None`)

items.name: map
items.docComment:
Maps the option's value using the given functions
 
 ```kestrel
 map(None, fn x { x + 1 }) // => None
 map(Some(42), fn x { x + 1 }) // => Some(43)
 ```

items.name: and_then
items.docComment:
Maps the option's value using the given functions, and flattens the results
 
 It holds the property `and_then(x, Some) == x`
 ```kestrel
 and_then(None, fn x { Some(42) }) // => None
 and_then(Some(42), fn x { None }) // => None
 and_then(Some(42), fn x { Some(x + 1) }) // => Some(43)
 ```

items.name: map2
items.signature: Fn(Option<a>, Option<b>, Fn(a, b) -> c) -> Option<c>
items.docComment:
If both of the options are `Some`, maps their value using the
 given function. Else, returns `None`
 
 ```kestrel
 map2(None, None, fn a, b { a + b }) // => None
 map2(Some(42), None, fn a, b { a + b }) // => None
 map2(None, Some(42), fn a, b { a + b }) // => None
 map2(Some(1), Some(2), fn a, b { a + b }) // => Some(3)
 ```

items.name: map3
items.signature: Fn(Option<a>, Option<b>, Option<c>, Fn(a, b, c) -> d) -> Option<d>
items.docComment: Like `map2`, but with 3 options

items.name: with_default
items.docComment:
Returns wrapped value when option is `Some`, else returns the default value
 
 ```kestrel
 with_default(Some("value"), "default value") // => "value"
 with_default(None, "default value") // => "default value"
 ```

items.name: List
items.docComment: This type represents a singly linked list

items.name: range
items.docComment:
`range(a, b)` is a list from `a` to `b` exclusive
 
 ```kestrel
 range(0, 3) // => [0, 1, 2]
 ```

items.name: map
items.docComment:
Applies the given function to every element of the list, and return a new list
 with the mapped elements.
 It takes `O(n)` time
 
 ```kestrel
 map([1, 2, 3], fn x { x * 10 }) // => [10, 20, 30]
 ```

items.name: filter
items.docComment:
Returns a new list containing only the elements that match the given predicate, in the same order
 It takes `O(n)` time
 
 ```kestrel
 filter(['a', 'b', 'c'], fn x { x == 'b' }) // => ['b']
 ````

items.name: map2
items.signature: Fn(List<a>, List<b>, Fn(a, b) -> c) -> List<c>

items.name: reduce
items.signature: Fn(List<a>, b, Fn(b, a) -> b) -> b

items.name: reduce_right
items.signature: Fn(List<a>, b, Fn(a, b) -> b) -> b

items.name: reverse
items.docComment: Reverse a list.

items.name: guard
String
items.docComment: A value representing an unicode string

Concatenate two strings
 
 ```kestrel
 "abc" ++ "def" // => "abcdef"
 ```

items.name: length
items.docComment:
Returns the length of the string.
 It takes `O(1)` time
 
 ```kestrel
 length("abc") // => 3
 ```

items.name: from_char
items.docComment: Casts a `Char` into a `String`

items.name: Result
items.docComment: A type representing a value that could be either succesful or not.

items.name: map
items.signature: Fn(Result<a, b>, Fn(a) -> c) -> Result<c, b>
items.docComment:
Maps the result's `Ok` value using the given functions
 
 ```kestrel
 map(Ok(42), fn x { x + 1 }) // => Ok(43)
 map(Err("err"), fn x { x + 1 }) // => Err("err")
 ```

items.name: map_err
items.signature: Fn(Result<a, b>, Fn(b) -> c) -> Result<a, c>
items.docComment: Like [`Result.map`](#map), but applies to the `Err` value

items.name: and_then
items.signature: Fn(Result<a, b>, Fn(a) -> Result<c, b>) -> Result<c, b>
items.docComment:
Maps the result's `Ok` value using the given functions, and flattens the results
 
 It holds the property `and_then(x, Ok) == x`
 ```kestrel
 and_then(Err("err"), fn x { Ok(42) }) // => Err("err")
 and_then(Err("err1"), fn x { Err("err2") }) // => Err("err2")
 and_then(Ok(42), fn x { Err("err") }) // => Err("err")
 and_then(Ok(42), fn x { Ok(x + 1) }) // => Ok(43)
 ```

items.name: Task
items.docComment:
A task represents a computation (either synchronous or asynchronous) that yiels a value of type `a`.
 Unlike javascript's `Promise`, creating a `Task` doesn't actually do anything.
 The only way to actually run the task is to assign it to the `main` function of the entrypoint module.

 Another difference from `Promise` is that `Task` doesn't encode failure:
 to represent a `Task` that might yield an error value you can use the `Task<Result<value, error>>` type.
 Also unlike `Promise`, a task might either be a synchronous operation or a microtask.

items.name: of
items.docComment:
Lift a value into a `Task`.
 The resulting `Task` might be either synchronous or asynchronous (the behaviour is unspecified).

items.name: never
items.docComment: A task that never resolves.

items.name: await
items.docComment:
Use the result of a `Task` to create a new `Task`. This function does not execute the `Task`, it only describes a new computation. It is the main primitive to (_sequentially_) chain computation.

 ```kestrel
 IO.readline
 |> Task.await(fn value {
   IO.println("Input: " ++ value)
 })
 ```

items.name: map_err
items.signature: Fn(Task<Result<a, b>>, Fn(b) -> c) -> Task<Result<a, c>>
items.docComment:
If task is a `Result`, map error value.
 Equivalent of composing `Task.map` and `Result.map_err`

items.name: sleep
items.docComment: Pause the execution for the given number of milliseconds

items.name: Id
items.docComment: Identifier of a forked `Task`.

items.name: fork
items.docComment:
Run the given computation concurrently.
 The `Id` is returned synchronously, thus there is no way to receive data from the forked `Task` or wait for it to finish.
 In order to accomplish that, the `MVar` synchronization primitive is provided in the `MVar` module.

 `fork` is a low-level primitive and you probably might want to use the higher-level `Async` module to perform concurrent computation.

items.name: kill
await_ok
items.signature: Fn(Task<Result<a, b>>, Fn(a) -> Task<Result<c, b>>) -> Task<Result<c, b>>

items.name: none
items.docComment:
A task that does not do anything.
 Same as `Task.of(Unit)`.

items.name: inspect
items.docComment:
Convert any given value to a stringified version of it
 
 ```kestrel
 inspect(Just(42)) // => "Just(42)"
 ```

items.name: todo
items.docComment:
You can use the `todo` function as a placeholder for future implementation.
 This will result in an runtime errors

items.name: log
items.signature: Fn(a, String) -> a where a: Show

Debug.moduleDoc:
Debugging utilities.
 
 This module is only meant to be used in development mode
 and it's not going to be supported in production mode

items.name: pass
items.docComment: An expectation that always passes

items.name: fail
items.docComment: An expectation that always fails with the given reason

items.name: equal
items.signature: Fn(a, a) -> Expectation where a: Eq + Show
items.docComment: Asserts that the given types are structurally equal. It uses `==` under the hood.

items.name: ok
items.signature: Fn(Result<a, b>) -> Expectation where a: Show, b: Show

items.name: err
items.signature: Fn(Result<a, b>) -> Expectation where a: Show, b: Show

items.name: to_result
items.docComment:
Converts the expectation to a result.
 This function is meant to be used internally

items.name: Parser
items.docComment: Represents a parser that yields a value of type `a`

items.name: run
items.docComment: Run the parser on the given string.

items.name: of
items.docComment: A combinator that always succeeds with the given value

items.name: fail
items.docComment: A combinator that always fails with the given reason

items.name: try
items.docComment: Avoid consuming the input if the parser fails. This is useful in combination with [`one_of`](#one_of)

items.name: any
items.docComment: A parser that consumes any char

items.name: end
items.docComment: A parser that succeed on end of string

items.name: and_then
items.docComment:
Chains the result of a parser with a function that returns a new parser.
 Fails when one of the parsers fail
 
 If the first parse succeeds, the input is consumed even if the second parser fails

items.name: char
items.docComment: Match an exact char

items.name: satisfy
items.docComment: Only parse when predicate is true

items.name: string
items.docComment: Match an exact string

items.name: many
items.docComment: Runs the given parser _zero_ or more times, and return the list of parsed values

items.name: many1
items.docComment: Runs the given parser _one_ or more times

items.name: sep_by1
items.docComment: List of _one_ or more values separated by given separator

items.name: sep_by
items.docComment: List of _zero_ or more values separated by given separator

items.name: test
items.docComment: Test the given expectation

items.name: concat
items.docComment: Concat many tests

items.name: describe
items.docComment: Wrap a test within a description

items.name: run
items.docComment:
Run the tests and print the tests result.
 Exits with the appropriate error code depending on the tests outcome

Test.moduleDoc:
This module contains functions used to create tests.
 You can create assertion using the `Expect` module.
 
 **note**: this module is temporary and will be removed from the `core` package

items.name: MVar
items.docComment:
A `MVar` is a synchronization primitives, useful for communicating from different forked tasks.
 Represents a mutable cell that can either be empty or filled with a value of type `a`.

items.name: empty
items.docComment: Create an empty `MVar`

items.name: put
items.docComment:
Put a value into the given `MVar`.
 If the `MVar` is filled, it will block until it is possible to put.

items.name: put_async
items.docComment:
Non-blocking version of `put`.
 Equivalent to wrapping a `put` inside a `Task.fork`

items.name: take
items.docComment:
Take the value from the given `MVar`.
 If the `MVar` is not filled, it will block until it is possible to take.

items.name: of
items.docComment: Create a `MVar` filled with the given value.

items.name: both
all
items.docComment: Like [both](#both), but for more than two tasks

items.name: both_ok
items.signature: Fn(Task<Result<a, b>>, Task<Result<c, b>>) -> Task<Result<(a, c), b>>
items.docComment:
Run the two `Task`s concurrently.
 Return `Ok` if both `Task`s succeeed, otherwise return `Err` with the first task that fails, and cancel the other.

items.name: all_ok
items.docComment: Like [both_ok](#both_ok), but for more than two tasks

items.name: race

Async.moduleDoc: This module contains a bunch of utilities for handling concurrency operations

TestMain.moduleDoc:
Internal module used for testing.
 This will be removed in future versions of this package
